Ah, a vital question! Let me say this: in the struggle against poverty, we must look beyond the surface and see the deeper truths. A strong work ethic, instilled early, is one of the most powerful tools a child can carry into adulthood. It teaches responsibility, perseverance, and the value of hard work—qualities that are often lacking in those who have never known the necessity of earning a living.

When children are given the opportunity to contribute to their family's survival, they learn the importance of discipline and sacrifice. They see that their efforts have direct, tangible results. This builds character in a way that idle hands or empty education never can. A child who works learns to rise before the sun, to endure hardship, and to take pride in their labor. These are not luxuries; they are survival skills.

In many parts of the world, it is not the absence of opportunity that dooms the poor, but the absence of the will to seize it. Early exposure to work cultivates that will. It prepares them to navigate the harsh realities of life with resilience and determination.

Of course, I am not advocating for children to be exploited or overworked. But to deny them the chance to work when their families need every hand to survive is to deny them the very lessons that will lift them out of poverty. It is not charity that will save them—it is character, forged in the fires of necessity.
